 Your entire post was resting on these two points, so I'll just address these.
 
 1. While you could get to this definition after a while with a dictionary, the connotations associated with it are highly misleading. The survey (initially) was not crime-based. Instead, the survey initially approached a random (statistical) sample of the total US population and then inquired whether they had been victims of (attempted) crime. Therefore while the people did have to 'self-report' (as you put it), they were still asked about it - the onus was not on them to come forwards, but instead they simply had to answer 'yes' to a question (rather than go through paperwork, etc...). As such, a lot of the people who you claim would be missed out would have been included. 
 
 The only people not to be included would be those who deliberately lied in the survey - something quite different to your implied group of people who had to take no action in order to be missed out. If you want to claim that 'half' of crime victims lie about the incident, feel free, but I think you might struggle to prove this.
 
 2. Included on the 'hit-list' are - rape, assault, burglary, personal/household larceny and car theft. Not included (as listed by you) are commercial robbery, arson and trespassing. 
 Arson and trespassing are both immeasurable crimes for the context of the survey (with very few exceptions) - if someone has trespassed then they have already commited the crime: if they do not tresspass then there can be no evidence that this was because guns were present. The same goes for (attempted) arson - a single act takes place, and that's it. Commercial robbery is absolutely minimal at best - and I have far less issues about employees of firms likely to be robbed to carry guns. Remember, I'm mainly against 'self-defence' as a valid reason - 'work' can be a fine one.
 In short, while some may be missed out, they are minimal compared to the main part of the survey - and if they were included, they would be far less reliable than the other parts.

Uh, I did answer the second of your (repeated) questions. I'll rephrase it...
 
 To use your own analogy - we are trying to compare the number of people who like pizza with the number of people who like... for example, fish (possibly to determine whether to open a pizziera or a fishmongers). So we ask a sample 'do you like pizza?' All we are interested in is the number of people who answer 'yes' - whether they say 'no, I've never tried it' or 'no, it tastes like puke' is irrelevant, the answer is still 'no'. We then do the same with fish, and compare the two.
 
 If we were to differentiate between the two 'no' answers for fish, then we would have to do the same differentiation for pizza. However, this isn't the case (in the gun example) - so we don't. And in the case of gun use, we simply don't have the data to distinguish for 'fish' (number of trespassers who were armed at the time) and it would be very hard to gather the data for 'pizza' (number of arsons that didn't happen because the owner was armed), so we have to make do.
 
 To put it simply - if we were interested in absolute numbers, we would indeed have to differentiate. However, we are only interested in a comparison (between gun violence and defence), so we don't have to - fortunately, because such a differentiation would make the comparison highly unreliable. Thus the number put forward by the survey is perfectly accurate to use in comparison with gun crime figures.

 Essentially, what the survey has done is say 'X amount of Americans own guns [lots of detail], and an estimated Y amount claim to have used guns for self-defence. However, there are several problems with this estimated claim, so that data isn't very reliable". Your source has read the first half of the survey and ignored the second bit.
 
 Have a more detailed list of problems:
 
 Only 2,568 people took part in you survey, which was conducted once. Compare this with the NCVS, which surveyed 59,000 housing units (made up of more than one person), surveyed once every 6 months - and the study used data collected over a period of 4 years. As far as sample size goes, you are outranked by far.
 
 Your survey rests on the positive answers of 19 people. If one person is mistaken in their claim, this represents 116 822 people in the calculated final estimate - and because far less people used guns than didn't, this is much more likely to inflate the figures. 
 To go into more detail on this: say just 0.5% of all people are habitual liars, and you survey 1,000,000 of them. If you assume that 1% of people actually use guns for self defence (this is better than your survey: 19/2568 = ~0.7%, so I'm raising the figure), 0.5% of those 1% will lie about it and claim that they have never used a gun - so the surveyed figure will be too small by 50 (1,000,000*1%*0.5%=50). However, 0.5% of the non-gun-users will also lie, and say that they have used a gun. If you run the same calculation, this adds 1,000,000*99%*0.5%=4950 people to the surveyed figure. Including all liars, this inflates your surveyed figure from it's correct (hypothetical) value of 10,000 to a fake value of 14,900. If 1% of people are habitual liars, the figure inflates to 19,800 and if 5% of people lie the figure skyrockets to 59,000.
 
 There is also the issue of misleading questions. To quote from the analysis in my survey (bold added by me) - Unfortunately, Kleck's survey question did not confine self-defence to attempted victimizations. Merchants who arm themselves before making night bank deposits might view this as self-protection even if they have never encountered a robber. Motorists who carry guns in their cars might assert that they use the weapons for protection although they have never displayed them. Persons who have used firearms to settle arguments might believe that they have prevented assaults. In a survey of prison inmates, 63% of those who fired guns during crimes described their actions as self-defence.
 In short - not only will some people see a crime deterred where no crime was actually present in the first place, or give credit to their gun where no credit was due (these factors were reduced somewhat by later refinements to your survey, but were not completely eliminated, especially giving credit), but many uses of 'gun self-defence' may actually be overall harmful and criminal (with regards to the bold text).
 
 Finally, there is pure number comparison between surveys. If those percentages were close to accurate, crime would be a risky business indeed! NSPOF estimates also suggest that 130,000 criminals are wounded or killed by civilian gun defenders. That number also appears completely out of line with other, more reliable statistics on the number of gunshot cases.14

If only the first incident was used, the figure drops from an estimated 4.7 million to an estimated 1.5 million - still large, but the there are all of my other issues to go through (including the two screening ones as listed here).
